title: Are Mathematics and Logic distinct? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, mathematics and logic are distinct.  Logic is the subbranch of mathematics devoted to studying mathematics itself. "Metamathematical" concepts like axioms and proofs can be formalized within logic, and in theory we could reduce any mathematical statement to a long string of logical symbols, but you won't find many geometers or statisticians that think of themselves as logicians.

Yes they are distinct. Mathematical logic is an area of mathematics which studies the notions of proof, axioms, truth, etc and applies them to the rest of mathematics. Other mathematicians use this work indirectly, but when, say, a topologist is writing a proof, they don't directly use the work of logicians. Mathematics is logical, but mostly it's not Logic. Mathematical Logic is not the entirety of the study of Logic. Philosophers do their own thing.
Logic is the study of 'inferences'. We make inferences in many things, in our natural languages, mathematics, etc. Mathematics is a subject unto itself which uses logic
logic,  per se is not sufficient to capture every possible theorem  or to establish consistency of a system. In addition,  formal logic misses most of the insights of geometry.
